[[Sega Saturn]] version (titled ''Sim Hospital'' as of October 1995) was in development and due for release in mid-1996, but was cancelled.{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=Killer Bullfrogs Launch Game|magazine=Mean Machines Sega|issue=36 |publisher=[[Emap International Limited]]|date=October 1995|pages=13|issn=0967-9014|location=Peterborough|department=News|url=https://archive.org/details/mean-machines-sega-magazine-36|accessdate=21 October 2016}} In 2012, ''Theme Hospital'' was 1997|issue=97|language=French|author=Éric Ernaux}} }} ''Theme Hospital'' received positive reviews. Critics noted the strong gameplay, detailed graphics, satisfying comedic tone, and voice acting performance, but fell conflicted on music, repetition, the artificial intelligence, and the user interface. The British magazine ''[[PC Gamer]]''{{'s}} Steve Owen praised the game's challenge and "cute" graphics, but criticised the interface. Frederick Claude of ''Coming Soon Magazine'' also complimented the graphics as "highly detailed", and the "very simple" user interface, although he criticised the repetitiveness and lack of multiplayer support that would later be introduced with a patch. [[GameSpot]]{{'s}} Trent Ward agreed about the graphics too, lauding them as "fantastic", and also complimented the "realistic" voice acting performance, and the humour, although he criticised the [[Artificial intelligence (video games)|artificial intelligence]] as "flawed". His conclusion was that the game "just doesn't fly". Bonnie James of [[EP Daily|The Electric Playground]] also liked the graphics, as well as the "lovely" opening sequence, but found the music "horrible". ''[[Computer and Video Games]]''{{'s}} Alex Huhtala concurred about the graphics, describing them as "large and colourful", but commented that the humour wears off after a while, although he felt it is good to begin with. Another reviewer who liked the graphics was Dawn Jepsen of ''[[Computer Gaming World]]'', who also praised the humour, especially the "wackiness" of the illnesses, and described the game as "delightful and absorbing". The humour was also approved by a reviewer of [[Jeuxvideo.com]], who, like other reviewers, lauded the graphics, by describing them as colourful. ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]''{{'s}} reviewer echoed others' views about the humour, describing it as something they had come to except from Bullfrog, but criticised the lack of multiplayer support. The humour was again praised by a reviewer of ''PC Power'', who said that the ailments enabled Bullfrog to have "hilarious" cures. The "thoroughly engrossing" gameplay, and the graphics were also complimented: it was stated that the bright colours gave hospitals a "cheerful look". ''Theme Hospital'' was described as a "fantastic title". Other comments from critics included ''[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]''{{'s}} reviewer's compliments of the balance of patients and illnesses against the player's resources, and his belief that the game is a refinement of its genre, and ''[[PC Zone]]''{{'s}} reviewers commendation of the detail: it was remarked that it gets players "helplessly immersed", and the game was awarded the ''PC Zone'' Classic accolade. Éric Ernaux of ''[[:fr:Gen4|Génération 4]]'' said the quality is "remarkable for a game of its genre". The PlayStation version's main problem, as noted by critics, was the controls. It was cited by reviewers from GameSpot, [[IGN]], Eurogamer, and ''Edge'' as a major downside. Its reception was not entirely negative: James Mielke of GameSpot also commended the addictiveness, and described the port as "almost completely intact". IGN agreed with others about the humour, by praising it as "wonderfully sick". It was further commented that the game's "brilliance" made it a "must-have". The sentiments about the controls and humour were echoed by Dan Whitehead of [[Eurogamer]], who reviewed it on the PlayStation Network. Absolute PlayStation's reviewers had a mixed view about the graphics: they criticised the resolution and colour palette, but complimented the sprites. The user interface was criticised as being reminiscent of a [[Fourth generation of video game consoles|16-bit game]]. Despite the criticisms, they agreed with others about the humour, and described the game as "a blast to play". In 1997, ''Theme Hospital'' appeared alongside ''Theme Park'' at #61 on ''PC Gamer''{{'}}s list of top 100 games,{{cite magazine|title=The PC Gamer Top 100|issue=45|magazine=[[PC Gamer]]|date=July 1997|publisher=[[Future plc]]|issn=1470-1693|page=61|location=Bath}} and was named in April as a Game of Distinction. === Legacy === On 13 November 2017, Oxymoron Games revealed that they were working {{For|other people named Thomas Lee|Thomas Lee (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Politician | name = Thomas Lee | image = ThomasLEE.JPG | width = 200px | caption = '''Governor
Burgess
Governor's Councillor''' | birth_date = 1690 | birth_place = Mount Pleasant at Machodoc River, [[Westmoreland County, Virginia|Westmoreland County]], [[Colony of Virginia]] | residence = Machodoc River, later [[Stratford Hall (plantation)|Stratford Hall Plantation]] | death_date ={{death date|1750|11|14|mf=y}} (aged 59-60) | death_place = Stratford Hall, [[Westmoreland County, Virginia|Westmoreland County]], Colony of Virginia | office = [[House of Burgesses]] | term_start = 1723 | term_end = 1733 | predecessor = | successor = | office2 = [[House of Burgesses#Governor's Council|Council of State of Virginia]] | term_start2 = 1733 | term_end2 = 1750 | predecessor2 = | successo2r = | office3 = [[Governor of Virginia]] | term_start3 = 1749 | term_end3 = 1750 | predecessor3 = [[Sir William Gooch, 1st Baronet|William Gooch]] | successor3 =[[Robert Dinwiddie]] | constituency3 = | party = | religion = | alma_mater = [[The College of William and Mary]] | occupation = | constituency = | majority = | spouse = [[Hannah Harrison Ludwell]] | children = [[Philip Ludwell Lee]], [[Richard Henry Lee]], [[Thomas Ludwell Lee]], [[Francis Lightfoot Lee]], [[William Lee (diplomat)|William]] and [[Arthur Lee (diplomat)|Arthur Lee]] | parents = [[Richard Lee II]]
Laetitia Corbin | website = | footnotes = }} '''Col. Thomas Lee''' ([[circa|c.]] 1690–November 14, 1750) was a leading political figure of colonial [[Virginia]]. He was a member of the [[Lee family]], a [[political dynasty]] which included many figures from the pre-[[American Revolutionary War]] era until the late 20th century. Lee became involved in politics in 1710 and he became the resident manager of the [[Northern Neck]] Proprietary for Lady Catherine Fairfax. After his father died, he inherited land in [[Northumberland County, Virginia|Northumberland]] and [[Charles County, Maryland|Charles County]]. Lee later acquired vast holdings in what are now [[Arlington County|Arlington]], [[Fairfax County|Fairfax]], [[Fauquier County|Fauquier]], [[Prince William County|Prince William]], and [[Loudoun County|Loudoun]] Counties. These properties were developed as tobacco plantations. When Lee married Hannah Harrison Ludwell in 1722, he benefited by the connections of the already established [[Harrison family]]. A year later he would become a member of the [[House of Burgesses]]. After Lee's home was burnt down by criminals, he lost almost all of his possessions and a fair sum of money. With donations received from [[Caroline of Ansbach]] and English Commissioners, he built his new home on the [[Potomac River]], naming it [[Stratford Hall (plantation)|Stratford Hall]]. Four years later in 1733, he was appointed to the [[Governor's Council]], upper house of the General Assembly. In 1747, he founded the [[Ohio Company|Ohio Company of Virginia]] with fellow Virginian colonists who wished to expand Virginia's territory into the [[Ohio River Valley]]. For a period of less than a year, in 1749, he became the ''[[de facto]]'' [[Governor of Virginia]] in place of the absent [[Sir William Gooch, 1st Baronet|William Gooch]]. Lee was favored for an appointment as governor by [[George II of England|George II]] but the colonist died in 1750. ==Biography== ===Early life=== Thomas Lee was born around 1690 at [[Mount Pleasant (Hague, Virginia)|Mount Pleasant]], on the [[Machodoc River]] in [[Westmoreland County, Virginia]]. His parents were [[Richard Lee II|Col. Richard Lee II]], "the scholar", and Laetitia Corbin. His ancestors had immigrated from [[Coton, Shropshire]], England to Virginia in 1642.{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | url = http://www.bbc.co.uk/shropshire/history/2003/02/lee_house.shtml | title = Shropshire: House with its roots in history | work = | publisher = BBC | accessdate = 2009-07-14 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070312042814/http://www.bbc.co.uk/shropshire/history/2003/02/lee_house.shtml |archivedate = 2007-03-12}}Alexander, Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History (1912) p.28 As the fourth son of the couple, Lee would not receive as large an inheritance as his older brothers. This did not prevent him from becoming successful in politics. Lee attended college at [[The College of William and Mary]] around 1700.''A Catalogue of the College of William and Mary in Virginia From its Foundation to the Present Time'' (Williamsburg, 1859) Lee's education was referred to as a "common Virginia education".Alexander, Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History (1912) p.47 He soon became interested in the working of the tobacco industry. He left home to work with his uncle Thomas Corbin in the tobacco business. ==Political career== [[File:Coat of Arms of the Lee Family.svg|175px|thumb|left|Coat of Arms of Thomas Lee]] Lee's political career began in 1710 when he was appointed as Naval Officer of the Potomac River. The position was previously held by his father and upon his resignation, Lee was appointed as the new Naval Officer. In 1711, Lee's uncle Thomas Corbin helped him gain the position of Virginia agent for the Northern Neck Proprietary. As a result, he was appointed by Catherine (Culpeper) Fairfax, Lady Fairfax, who was living in England, as her agent and resident manager for the Northern Neck Proprietary, which she had inherited from her father, Governor [[Thomas Colepeper, 2nd Baron Colepeper]]. Catherine was the wife of [[Thomas Fairfax, 5th Baron Fairfax]]. This property, which consisted of approximately six million acres (24,000 km²), included all the land between the [[Potomac River|Potomac]] and [[Rappahannock River|Rappahnnock]] rivers. At one time [[Edmund Jenings]], another Lee uncle, headed this Proprietary. While Jenings was in England, the offices of the agency were located at the plantation at Machodoc and under Lee's supervision.[[Fairfax Harrison]], ''Virginia Land Grants: A Study of Conveyancing in Relation to Colonial Politics'' (1925; reprinted, New York, 1979), pp.98-100. Due to Jening's poor management,Calhoun. Thomas Lee of Stratford, 1690-1750: Founder of a Virginia Dynasty (1991) the agency was given to Governor [[Robert Carter I|Robert "King" Carter]] in 1720. This event led to animosity between the competitive Lee and Carter families.Dowdey, Clifford. ''The Virginia Dynasties: The Emergence of 'King' Carter and the Golden Age'' (1969) p.354 The members of the families refused to marry each other until [[Henry Lee III|Henry "Light Horse Harry" Lee]] married Anne Hill Carter. Henry and Anne's most notable child was [[Robert E. Lee]]. Thomas held this position until 1722. In 1713, Thomas succeeded his father as Naval Officer in charge of collecting customs for the south side of the Potomac. In 1714, upon his father's death, Lee inherited lands in [[Northumberland County, Virginia|Northumberland County]] near Dividing Creek, as well as land in Maryland adjoining his brother [[Philip Lee, Sr.]] of "[[Blenheim (Maryland)|Blenheim]]". Thomas leased the estate "Machodoc" from his brother [[Richard Lee III]] who was in London. That same year Thomas visited England, remaining for about a year. Lee thought that marriage was not only important between two individuals but for their families. A nephew of his later said, "Our Late Hon[ora]ble & worthy Unkle Presid[ent] Lee said that the first fall & ruin of families and estates was mostly Occasioned by Imprudent Matches to Imbeggar families and estates & to beget a race of beggars."Henry Lee to Richard Lee, 22 Feb. 1758, Box 1, ''Custis-Lee Papers,'' Library of Congress He was engaged to Jenny Wilson in 1716. That year he returned to England to formalize the lease to the plantation before he married. Before his return, Jenny Wilson had found another husband, [[James Roscoe]]. Lee learned this from [[William Byrd II|William Byrd]]. Lee and his brother [[Henry Lee I|Henry]] negotiated a lease for 99 years on the plantation. During his stay in England, Lee had decided to buy some property on the [[Potomac River]] called the "Clifts Plantation" in Westmoreland County. At the time, the property was owned by Nathaniel Pope, Jr., a mariner, of London. Lee believed that when Virginia gained its independence, the capital would be located on the Potomac River.Martin, ''Behind the Scenes in Washington: Being a Complete and Graphic Account of the Credit Mobilier Investigation'' (1873) p. 34 He later renamed it as [[Stratford Hall (plantation)|Stratford]]. Thomas purchased his father's old estate "Machodoc", from his sister-in-law, Martha Silk, the former wife of his older brother, Richard Lee III. "Machodoc" was later known as "Mount Pleasant". ===Marriage and family=== [[File:Hannahlee.jpg|thumb|right|Portrait of Lee's wife Hannah]] In May 1722, Thomas Lee married Hannah Harrison Ludwell (December 5, 1701 – January 25, 1750), a member of the prominent [[Harrison family]], at "Greenspring", James City County, Virginia.{{cite book|last=Nagel|first=Paul C.|authorlink=Paul C. Nagel|url=https://books.google.com/?id=UbyPlhZeKZIC&pg=PA39&lpg=PA39&dq=Hannah+Harrison+Ludwell|title=The Lees of Virginia|page=39|publisher=Oxford University Press|accessdate=2009-07-14|isbn=978-0-19-507478-9|date=1991-08-01}} The marriage lasted his life and brought him increased wealth and status. Hannah was the daughter of [[Philip Ludwell II]] of "[[Greenspring]]", and [[Hannah Harrison]]. The couple had eleven children; eight survived to adulthood: * Richard Lee (b. 1723) *[[Philip Ludwell Lee]] (February 24, 1726 – February 21, 1775) * John Lee (b. 1728 d. 1782) * Hannah Ludwell Lee (February 1729 – 1782) * [[Thomas Ludwell Lee]] (December 13, 1730 – April 13, 1778); a member of the Virginia Delegates and editor of the [[Virginia Declaration of Rights]].Alexander, ''Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History'' (1912) p.73 * [[Richard Henry Lee]] (January 20, 1732 – January 19, 1794); signer of the [[United States Declaration of Independence]]Alexander, ''Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History'' (1912) p. 86 & p. 103 * [[Francis Lightfoot Lee]] (October 14, 1734 – January 11, 1797); signer of the [[United States Declaration of Independence]]. Married Rebecca Tayloe, daughter of [[John Tayloe II]] of [[Mount Airy, Richmond County, Virginia|Mount Airy]]. Tayloe built [[Menokin]] for his daughter and her new husband. * Alice Lee (June 4, 1736 – March 25, 1817) * [[William Lee (diplomat)|William Lee]] (August 31, 1737 – June 27, 1795) * James Lee (b. and d. 1739) * [[Arthur Lee (diplomat)|Arthur Lee]] (December 21, 1740 – December 12, 1792) 1728 was a tragic year for Lee and his family. On January 29, thieves broke into the house stealing the Lee family plate, jewelry, and other articles of value, and upon leaving, set fire to the plantation house at Machodoc. The fire destroyed the entire plantation, including Thomas' office, the barns, and outhouses. Almost all of the Lees' possessions were destroyed, as well as up to 10,000 pounds in cash (equal to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|10000|1728}}}} today).''Maryland Gazette,'' 25 March - 1 April 1729 The house quickly burned and Hannah Lee, being pregnant with her fourth child, had to be thrown from her chamber window on the second floor. This resulted in Hannah's miscarriage of a son (they named him John). also injured in the fire was a slave girl, who died.The Lees of Virginia p.41 Virginia Governor [[Sir William Gooch, 1st Baronet|William Gooch]] blamed transported convicts for the crime. It is said that Col. Lee's loss was not less than 50,000 pounds (equal to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|50000|1728}}}} today). English Commissioners later gave Lee 300 pounds (equal to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|300|1728}}}} today) as compensation and [[Caroline of Ansbach|Queen Caroline]] also gave him money from her private purse to help with rebuilding.Hamilton and Hamilton, ''The Life of Robert E. Lee for Boys and Girls'' (1917), p.3Alexander, Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History (1912) pp.48,59 The convicts and an accomplice were later found guilty. Their punishment is unknown because the trial records were destroyed. When construction began on the new Lee mansion, the family stayed with Thomas's brother Henry at [[Lee Hall, Virginia|Lee Hall]]. Lee sold the "Machodoc" estate to Richard Lee III's son, George Lee, who built "Mount Pleasant". Lee's political career required trips to [[Williamsburg, Virginia|Williamsburg]], causing him to be away from his family for extended periods of time. Lee managed to make the 80-mile (130-km) journey to his family and to be with his wife at the births of each of their children.Carl Bridenbaugh, ''Seat of Empire: The Political Role of Eighteenth-Century Williamsburg'' (Williamsburg, 1950), p. 18; Westmoreland County Court Orders, 1731-1739, Part 1, p.46A, Westmoreland County Courthouse. Several of the sons became high-ranking political figures and were active in the [[American Revolutionary War]] and post-Revolution politics. Richard Henry was a senator from Virginia to the [[United States Senate]] and Francis Lightfoot was in the Virginia Senate. Lee's youngest sons [[William Lee (diplomat)|William Lee]] and [[Arthur Lee (diplomat)|Arthur Lee]] served as diplomats to various European countries.Alexander, ''Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History'' (1912) p.110 William, along with [[Jan de Neufville]], drafted an unofficial treaty between the United States and [[the Netherlands]] which [[Great Britain]] used as a reason for the [[Fourth Anglo-Dutch War]].{{cite web|url=http://www.leearchive.info/wl/index.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20070929184030/http://www.leearchive.info/wl/index.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-09-29 |title=William Lee|publisher=Lee Family Digital Archive|accessdate=2007-08-15 }} Lee later became a vestryman for Copole Parish and [[Justice of the Peace]] in Westmoreland County.Calhoun, Jeanne A., "Thomas Lee 1690-1750: A Preliminary Report," (prepared for the Robert E. Lee Memorial Association, 1988), pp. 10-14. In 1723, Lee became a member of the House of Burgesses. He held this office until he was appointed to the [[House of Burgesses#Governor's Council|Governor's Council]] in the [[Virginia General Assembly]] in 1733. This position was a lifetime appointment. The Council was made up of twelve appointees who were selected by the Governor of Virginia and was the upper half of the Virginia General Assembly. The lower half was made up of the [[House of Burgesses]]. This position also gave Lee the rank of Colonel, a military rank that was second only to the governor. Members of the Council were advisers to the governor and judges in the General Court of the colony. Their work led them to spend about a third of the year in the capital Williamsburg. When Governor William Gooch was recalled to England in 1749, Lee was named President of the King's Council of Virginia and Commander-in-Chief of the colony. Nominated for appointment as Governor of Virginia by [[George II of Great Britain|King George II]], he died before it took place.Hall, ''Executive Journals,'' V, pp.299-300. 53.Lee, Lee of Virginia pp. 121-123.Alexander, ''Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History'' (1912) p.48 ===Ohio Company=== Lee was appointed commissioner, along with [[William Beverley]], to negotiate with the [[Six Nations of the Iroquois]] at the [[Treaty of Lancaster]] in 1744.Hall, ''Executive Journals''V, p. 139. At the treaty, an agreement was made with the Six Nations for 400 pounds (equal to £{{formatnum:{{Inflation|UK|400|1744}}}} today) in return for the right for Virginians to travel through and settle in the [[Shenandoah Valley]].{{cite web|url=http://earlytreaties.unl.edu/treaty.00003.html |title=Ratified treaty # 3 A Treaty Held at the Town of Lancaster, By the Honourable the Lieutenant Governor of the Province, and the Honourable the Commissioners for the Province of Virginia and Maryland, with the Indians of the Six Nations in June, 1744. Van Doren, C. and Boyd, J. P. (Eds.). (1938). ''Indian Treaties Printed by Benjamin Franklin, 1736–1762.'' Philadelphia, PA: The Historical Society of Pennsylvania, 41–79 |publisher=University of Nebraska at Lincoln |accessdate=2013-04-22}} In 1747, Lee co-founded the [[Ohio Company|Ohio Company of Virginia]] along with [[Lawrence Washington (1718-1752)|Lawrence Washington]], [[Augustine Washington, Jr.]], the [[John Russell, 4th Duke of Bedford|Duke of Bedford]], and John Hanbury. The Ohio Company was a land speculation venture which helped colonize the [[Ohio Country]]. Lee's influence as a member of the Governor's Council helped lead to the success of the Ohio Company and within seven years the company had 100 families living in Ohio. He was also the first president of the Company and after Lee died, was succeeded by Lawrence Washington. ===Stratford Hall=== {{main|Stratford Hall (plantation)|}} [[File:Stratford hall habs 1.jpg|225px|thumb|right| Stratford Hall Plantation, built by Thomas Lee.]] With Lee's higher rank in society and wealth, he decided he needed to build a mansion to secure his position as one of the Virginia gentry. he chose the "Clifts," which he had owned since the mid-1710s. Lee decided on this site because it was located in Westmoreland County, where he was born, and because it was located on the Potomac River. The land was sufficient for having many construction laborers live there. Hannah had an influential say in the design and planning of the interior of the house. Philip, the couple's eldest son, had said, "See what it is to be ruled by a woman. I should have been now living in a house like this ... had not my father been persuaded by his wife to put up this very inferior dwelling, now over my head."Charles Carter Lee Papers, Box 9. The exact construction date of the house is unknown but it is estimated that construction began around 1725-30, as all of Lee's sons were born at Stratford. Workers on the plantation were from all the working class: free people and [[indentured servants]] mostly from the British Isles, and African slaves.Jack and Marion Kaniinkow, eds., ''A List of Emigrants to America 1718-1759'' (Baltimore, 1964), p. 163; Calhoun, "Thomas Lee," p. 16. Between 1719 and 1746, Lee acquired vast holdings in what are now [[Arlington County|Arlington]], [[Fairfax County|Fairfax]], [[Fauquier County|Fauquier]], [[Prince William County|Prince William]], and [[Loudoun County|Loudoun]] counties. The town of [[Leesburg, Virginia|Leesburg]], was named in his honor as recommended by his two sons, who were the founders and trustees. Hannah Harrison died at "Stratford" on January 25, 1749, having borne eleven children. She was buried in the old family burying ground, called the "Burnt House Fields", at "Mount Pleasant". Her tombstone was later removed to "[[Stratford Hall (plantation)|Stratford Hall]]", probably by Henry Lee, who built the new vault at that place. On November 14, 1750, Thomas Lee died at age sixty and was buried in the old "Burnt House Fields" at Mount Pleasant. According to his will, he wished to be buried in between his wife and his mother. He bequeathed Stratford Hall to his eldest son, Philip Ludwell Lee, and the Machodoc plantation to his nephew, [[George Lee (colonist)|George Lee]]. ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} == References == {{refbegin}} * {{cite book |last=Alexander |first=Frederick Warren |authorlink= |title=Stratford Hall and the Lees Connected with its History |url=https://books.google.com/books?vid=OCLC01119172&id=tlIEAAAAIAAJ&printsec=titlepage |year=1912 |publisher=Frederick Warren Alexander |location=Oak Grove, Virginia |isbn= }} * {{cite book |last=Bridenbaugh |first=Carl |authorlink= |title=Seat of Empire: The Political Role of Eighteenth-Century Williamsburg |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cM3C8PjrcOsC&q=Seat+of+Empire:+The+Political+Role+of+Eighteenth-Century+Williamsburg&dq=Seat+of+Empire:+The+Political+Role+of+Eighteenth-Century+Williamsburg&pgis=1 |year=1958 |publisher=[[Holt, Rinehart and Winston|Holt]] |location=New York, New York |isbn= }} * {{cite journal |last=Calhoun |first=Jeanne A. |authorlink= |date=December 1991 |title=Thomas Lee of Stratford, 1690-1750: Founder of a Virginia Dynasty |journal=Northern Neck of Virginia Historical Magazine |volume=XLI |issue=1 |pages= |url= http://www.stratfordhall.org/thomas.html|accessdate= 2009-07-14 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070927172134/http://www.stratfordhall.org/thomas.html |archivedate= 2007-09-27}} * {{cite book |last=Campbell |first=Charles |authorlink= |title=History of the Colony and Ancient Dominion of Virginia |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=u_9DZ6Yx0oAC&dq=History+of+the+Colony+and+Ancient+Dominion+of+Virginia |year=1860 |publisher= J. B. Lippincott & co. |location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania |isbn= }} * {{cite book |last=Hamilton |first=Mary |authorlink= |author2=J.G. de Roulhac Hamilton |title=The Life of Robert E. Lee for Boys and Girls |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oP4krOQm_ZoC&dq=The+Life+of+Robert+E.+Lee+for+Boys+and+Girls |year=1917 |publisher= Houghton Mifflin Company |location=Boston |isbn= }} * {{cite book |last=Lee |first=Edmund Jennings |authorlink= |title=Lee of Virginia 1642-1892 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TAoxAAAAMAAJ&q=Lee+of+Virginia+1642-1892&dq=Lee+of+Virginia+1642-1892&pgis=1 |year=1895 |publisher= Genealogical Pub. Virginia Cretella | relatives = siblings: [[Marijke Mars]], [[Pamela Mars-Wright]] and [[Victoria B. Mars]] }} '''Valerie Anne Mars''' (born 20 January 1959) is an American billionaire [[Inheritance|heiress]] and businesswoman.{{cite web|title=Valerie Mars|url=https://origin-www.bloomberg.com/billionaires/profiles/valerie-a-mars/|publisher=Bloomberg Billionaire Index, bloomberg.com| accessdate=2018-04-06}} In March 2018 Forbes estimated her wealth to be $5.9 billion. She was ranked as the 30th richest woman in the world - a position shared with her three sisters.{{cite web|title=The World's Billionaires 2018, Women |url=https://www.forbes.com/billionaires/list/#version:static_tab:women|publisher=Forbes, forbes.com| accessdate=2018-04-06}} Valerie Mars is a fourth generation member of the [[Mars family]]. Her father was late [[Forrest Mars Jr.]] (1931–2016). She has three sisters: [[Marijke Mars]], [[Pamela Mars-Wright]] and [[Victoria B. Mars]].{{cite web|title= Forrest E. Mars Jr., enigmatic steward of family confectionery, dies at 84 |publisher= washingtonpost.com |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/forrest-e-mars-jr-enigmatic-steward-of-family-confectionery-dies-at-84/2016/07/27/0265c442-5400-11e6-b7de-dfe509430c39_story.html | author= Emily Langer| date= 2016-07-27 |accessdate=2018-04-06}} She inherited about 8 percent stake of [[Mars, Incorporated|Mars Inc.]] in 2016, which made her a [[billionaire]]. According to [[Forbes]], her shares were valued worth of $5.9 billion (March 2018).{{cite web|title= The World's Billionaires: 296. Victoria Mars |publisher= Forbes |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/valerie-mars/?list=billionaires|year=2018|accessdate=2018-04-06}} She graduated (B.A./B.Sc.) from [[Yale University]] and has MBA from [[Columbia University]]. She is married and has two children.{{cite web|title= Valerie A. Mars To Wed Teacher|publisher=The New York Times | date=1984-04-22 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/22/style/valerie-a-mars-to-wed-teacher.html|accessdate=2018-04-06}} She is a senior vice president and head of corporate development for Mars, Inc. Since 2014 she has served as a board member of [[Fiat Chrysler Automobiles]].{{cite web|title=Valerie Anne Mars. Non-Executive Director, Fiat Chrysler Automobiles N.V.|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=662423&privcapId=320105|publisher=Bloomberg, bloomberg.com| accessdate=2018-04-06}}{{cite web|title=Valerie A. Mars|url=https://www.fcagroup.com/en-US/group/governance/board_of_directors/Pages/valerie_mars.aspx|publisher=Fiat Chrysler Automobiles N.V., fcagroup.com| accessdate=2018-04-06}} She serves also as a board member of [[Ahlstrom|Ahlstrom-Munksjö]], a [[Finland|Finnish]]-Swedish stock company (paper industry).{{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=https://www.ahlstrom-munksjo.com/About-us/Organization/Board-of-Directors/ |publisher=Ahlstrom-Munksjö, ahlstrom-munksjo.com| accessdate=2018-04-06}} She is member of the advisory board of [[Rabobank|Rabobank North America]]. Her participation in [[nonprofit organization]]s include board membership in [[Conservation International]] (nature protection){{cite web|title=Board of Directors|url=https://www.conservation.org/about/pages/board-of-directors.aspx |publisher=Conservation International, conservation.org| accessdate=2018-04-07}} and the [[Open Space Institute]] (landscape protection, honorary trustee).{{cite web|title=Board of Trustees|url=https://www.openspaceinstitute.org/board-of-trustees |publisher=Open Space Institute, openspaceinstitute.org| accessdate=2018-04-07}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mars, Valerie}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1959 births]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Columbia University alumni]] [[Category:American philanthropists]] [[Category:Mars family]] [[Category:American billionaires]] [[Category:Female billionaires]]
